rh:doc.headline: CV 1.1 Storage
rh:doc.parentIdentifier9: CV 1. Receipt, Storage and Delivery of Vehicles

articles.content: Policy
Stored vehicles are to be protected and maintained up to factory standards
Requirement

Criteria that must be adhered to:

  • Proper protection and maintenance prior to retail is solely dealer's responsibility.
  • Any damages or needed repairs must be completed prior to dealer storage.
  • Vehicle must be stored/parked on a paved or permanently hard surface.
  • To avoid airborne fallout, vehicles should not be stored under lights, power lines/poles or trees.
  • If exposed to sunlight, vehicle position should be rotated every 30 days to avoid sun damage.
  • Vehicle must be stored in well drained dry location to prevent rust or water/flood damage.
  • Soft trim should be cleaned to avoid/prevent premature deterioration.
  • The vehicle’s interior must be kept dry and actions must be taken to prevent moisture from condensing inside the vehicle.
  • To avoid tire flat spots and brake pulsation and vibration, the vehicle must be moved to a new parking spot or moved forward or backward at least one half tire rotation every 30 days.
  • Tire pressure must also be checked and maintained at the maximum MBUSA recommended tire pressure, at least once every 30 days.
Guideline/Practical Example
For vehicles being placed in storage reference WIS ap00.70-p-1000zz and si54.10-p-0024a for battery information.

articles.supplementarytopicstitle: CV 4. Warranty Labor and Part Rate Reimbursement

articles.content: Policy

If, during the course of repairing a Mercedes-Benz/Freightliner component under Warranty, an eXpertUpfitter’s component needs to be removed and reinstalled, the dealer may charge the time to do this using labor operation (Op-Code) 92-0600 (refer to Policy 4.0 Labor Reimbursement). This must be explained in the claim and be supported by the Repair Order. This time must not overlap with any time that may exist in XOT for the removal/reinstallation of the OEM component. Conversely, if the eXpertUpfitter component must be removed/reinstalled by the upfitter, the amount charged may be billed as a SUBLET (refer to Policy 7.4.0 Sublet Repairs)

Exclusions:

If the failure of the Mercedes-Benz/Freightliner component is directly or indirectly caused by an upfitter’s component, the reimbursement of any and all of the repair costs will be the responsibility of the upfitter. Likewise, if the cause of the repair is a failure of the eXpertUpfitters component no reimbursement will be made by MBUSA Warranty for the removal/reinstallation of Mercedes-Benz/Freightliner components.
Policy

If a vehicle that has been sold to an eXpertUpfitters needs warranty work performed on the original Mercedes-Benz/Freightliner portion of the unit, the eXpertUpfitter or its representative may have the work performed at any authorized Mercedes-Benz or Freightliner Service Center.

Note: Only OEM (Mercedes-Benz/Freightliner) components of the unit are covered under the terms of the NVLW and any applicable MBUSA service contracts. The parts installed by the upfitter may carry their own warranty and customer must refer to those and the upfiter’s authorized or recommended service centers for the handling of non-OEM warranty repairs/reimbursements.
Procedure

Prior to sale to end-customer (and under 3500 miles): Upon submission of claim EVA may show error: 051: Vehicle Has >=500 Miles (3500 Miles if upfitted Sprinter/Metris) and Needs to be Registered with MBUSA. Dealer must check the “No Reg.” box to allow claim in.

Once the vehicle has been sold to end-customer or if the vehicle has over 3500 miles the Warranty Start Date must be registered through the Upfitter Portal.
Policy

Unlike passenger vehicles and other Commercial Van accounts, basic Mercedes-Benz Commercial Van chassis will be sold to eXpertUpfitters, completed by the upfitter with their equipment according to the Commerical Van Customer Assurance Program and displayed for sale at the respective upfitter's franchised dealerships. The upfitting process takes several weeks, then the completed vehicle is marketed and sold.

In recognition of the lead-time between the delivery of the chassis or vehicle to the eXpertUpfitter and the ultimate customer retail delivery, the warranty will be delayed for a maximum of 24 months or 3,500 miles from the date of production. The vehicle warranty is automatically started at the time of the van purchase, but can be updated one time after upfit with the customer information via the Upfitter Portal Delayed Warranty Form page ( Mercedes-Benz Vans Upfitter Portal-Delayed Warranty Form) or if beyond the 24 months from production.
Requirement

The benefit of a delayed Warranty Start Date is only available to vehicles sold to eXpertUpfitter program upfitters. Vehicles sold to non-program upfitters are not eligible and the Warranty Start Date must remain as the date the vehicle was initially retailed.

The Warranty Start Date must be the date of sale to the ultimate customer of the upfitted unit but cannot be more than 24 months from production date of the Mercedes-Benz or Freightliner Van chassis. Special consideration to apply a date that is greater than this period will not be granted.
Procedure

In order to offer the eXpertUpfitter’s customers the full benefit of the factory warranty, the upfitter or their authorized representative will record the Warranty Start Date as the date the completed vehicle is retailed by an eXpertUpfitter’s franchised dealer to a customer via the Upfitter Portal.

To access the Delayed Start Warranty form please visit the Upfitter Portal.

This section consists of the special provisions that are unique to upfitted/modified vehicles. These are vehicles that are modified by an upfitter (i.e. bodybuilder or coachbuilder).

These special provisions are only granted to vehicles that have been upfitted under the eXpertUpfitter program as defined by Mercedes-Benz USA Upfitter Management.

Note: Vehicles that are sold to and/or upfitted by non-eXpertUpfitter program bodybuilders are not eligible to any of the provisions contained within this section.

For information regarding the eXpertUpfitter program please go to the Upfitter Portal.
Policy

The servicing dealer is required to ensure that the information being entered on the Repair Order is accurate. Accepting an “estimated” mileage from a customer or generating a VIN from a dealer’s DMS or CRM system without verification is not acceptable. Dealer personnel must inspect and verify that the VIN and mileage on the Repair Order is the same as on the actual vehicle being serviced.

Dealers must be diligent in insuring correct VIN information on Repair Orders. When errors occur, Service Management must identify the cause of the error and take steps to prevent it from reoccurring.
Procedure

Do NOT self-debit the claim

Scenario I - Incorrect VIN was claimed by your dealership:

  • Gather all supporting documentation to support the transfer of the claim to the correct VIN.
  • Fill out the one VIN Discrepancy Form for each Repair Order and have the appropriate signatures.
  • Create a case using the VIN that is currently on the claim (i.e. the incorrect VIN); attach the completed and signed form (both SM and Operator must sign) and any supporting documentation to the case.

Scenario II – Incorrect VIN was claimed by a different dealership:

  • The discovering dealer must inform the first dealer.
  • The discovering dealer may contact their Field Representative for assistance if the first dealer is nonresponsive.
    • In this case, the discovering dealer’s Field Representative will work with the first dealer’s Field Representative for a resolution.
  • The VIN Discrepancy Form must be filled out, signed and submitted via a case created by the servicing dealer that originally submitted the claim with incorrect VIN.
  • If it is determined that the original servicing dealership is no longer in service, Warranty Services will determine the next steps
Policy

The servicing dealer is required to follow state law and to ensure that the information being entered on the Repair Order is accurate and that the customer is supplied with complete and accurate details as to the repairs performed on their vehicle. In instances when a part is left off an RO, but installed on a vehicle, the dealer is obligated to make sure the customer is brought back and supplied with a new RO documenting the parts installed during their last visit. This must be remedied, and claim resubmitted within 30 days from credit note date.
Procedure

Bring the customer’s vehicle back within 30 days of the credit note date. If this has taken place beyond 30 days or all appropriate information is not supplied, the claim is subject to debit.

The following information is required.

  • Photos of newly installed parts
  • Photo of VIN plate from B-Pillar or seat base of driver’s seat (location dependent on vehicle model)
  • A new Repair Order must be opened with the part billed out explaining that the part was installed on previous ROXXXX, but inadvertently left off the RO. This must be signed by the customer.
  • A Quick Test must be uploaded to pXD showing the time and miles that match the new RO

Self-Debit the original claim then recreate the claim using the original RO information including RO number, mileage, and RO open/close dates, with the addition of the omitted parts (which should be added last on the Parts Number section).

Once this information and documentation is complete, the dealer will need to confirm the 099 error affirming all information is attached.

Note: In instances for campaigns, if the customer cannot return to the dealer, the dealer must open a case to request the campaign be reopened. Without doing this, both the dealership and MBUSA become exposed to potential liability in the event there is a related failure in the vehicle.

articles.attachmentTitle: EVA - Self-Debit strike out parts and labor
EVA - Self-Debit to reduce part quantity or labor time

articles.content: Policy

Under certain circumstances, dealers can self-debit their claims within 30 days after receiving a paid credit memo from MBUSA. This can be done when tax is omitted, or for parts that are billed on the RO that were left off claim submission, sublets that are compliant with Policy 7.4, or labor which is supported by technician time punches and uploaded documentation.
Procedure

Perform the self-debit in EVA or RAPS. After the self-debit, the claim must be reentered using the same exact information on the RO. All paperwork must be attached to the new claim. For claims adding labor, a Labor Discrepancy form must be completed and attached to the new EVA claim. EVA will produce an 099 error and the dealer must confirm this error, explain the reason for the rework, and affirm all required documents are attached.

To adjust the requested percentages down on a claim without changing the parts or labor operations or to request a self-debit for a comeback beyond the 30-day period, please open a case under Post Claim Submission for assistance.

Note: All RO information on the new claim must be exactly the same as the original submission. Adding or altering information is prohibited, this includes adding letters or additional numbers to an RO number to bypass the 099 error.

Note: Claims requesting time adjustments are subject to review of the entire RO. The entire RO must be compliant with time punch policy and all supporting documents uploaded into pXD. There must be sufficient time punched and it must be punched properly to justify the change in time.
Guideline/Practical Example

Some examples of when not to self-debit:

  • In lieu of appealing a decision on a claim
  • Beyond 30 days from the credit date on a claim

articles.attachmentTitle: EVA Claim Review - how to appeal a claim

articles.content: Policy

Dealers can appeal a claim that was decided and has a credit note issued. If the dealer disagrees with a claim decision, the dealer may appeal the claim within 90 calendar days after payment or decision date. Due to administrative processes, appeals after this period will not be reviewed/honored.

Claims that were decided during a dealership audit are not subject to this policy; specific appeal instructions will be provided at the close of the audit.
Procedure

Do not open a case to appeal a denied claim, unless it is a Part-Test appeal. All appeals must be handled within the appropriate claiming system. Follow all instructions given by the Controller and attach all required documents. If a claim is denied, never reenter without appealing for permission from the Controller first.
Guideline/Practical Example

• Once an appeal is submitted MBUSA has 30 days (or subject to State Statutes) to review the appeal.
  • If documents submitted in the appeal are different from the originally provided documents, these are considered “altered documents” and will not justify overturning a previous decision
  • Claims can be marked Final Decision and to appeal these it requires a Final Decision Appeal Form to be submitted in Star Support. Please see supplementary documents below for the form.
  • Parts Testing appeals must be handled through the case system, not EVA, if a case is marked as final decision, the dealer can appeal using the Part Testing Appeal form submitted in Star Support.
  • Non Return parts require a Non Return Parts Appeal form to be filed in Star Support.
This section details procedures taken after a claim is submitted, such as appeals, rework and reentering a claim, and VIN Discrepancies.

rh:doc.headline: CV 10.5 Reimbursement to Owners for Repairs Performed Prior to Recall
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: CV 10.5 Reimbursement to Owners for Repairs Performed Prior to Recall

articles.content: Policy

Certain Recall Campaign documentation states that repairs prior to the release of the recall may be eligible for reimbursement (i.e. customer originally paid for the repair to be performed prior to the launch of the campaign). Not every Recall campaign will be eligible for possible Owner reimbursement. Recall Campaign documentation will stipulate when Owner reimbursement is applicable. A notification of eligibility will be sent to the owner if there vehicle may qualify for reimbursement.

For replacement equipment, the manufacturer may limit the amount of the reimbursement to the ordinary retail price of the item that was replaced.

The final rule does not require the pre-recall remedy to be identical to the remedy elected by the manufacturer.

Mercedes-Benz is permitted to exclude reimbursement if the pre-notification remedy:

  • Was not substantially the same type remedy as the one performed in the Recall
  • Did not address the issue that led to the Recall
  • Was not reasonably necessary
  • Was not supported with adequate documentation by the Owner to Mercedes-Benz.

Note: The TREAD (Transportation Recall Enhancement, Accountability and Documentation) Act, created by the U.S. Congress in November 2000, created a mandatory obligation on the part of Vehicle manufacturers to provide vehicle owner reimbursement for some pre-recall expenditures, to reimburse vehicle owners for any costs they incurred in remedying a defect or non-compliance included as part of or directly related to the Recall, prior to a Recall notification.
Requirement

Once the dealer has determined the customer is eligible for reimbursement; the dealers are required to submit a claim for owner reimbursement.

Adequate documentation is required and includes:

  • Name and address of the person seeking reimbursement
  • Total cost of the repair expense with proof of payment for repair
  • What problem occurred, what repair was done, when it was done and who repaired it
  • Proof the person owned the Recalled VIN at the time of repair

Owners are not required to complete repairs at an authorized Mercedes-Benz dealer. Appropriate documentation confirming the repair from an independent repair facility is acceptable.

Exceptions:

  • Manufacturers are not required to pay repairs that did not address the problems addressed by the Recall.
  • The regulation does not require reimbursement for injuries, property damage, rental vehicles, or missed employment allegedly arising from the vehicle condition subject to the Recall.
Procedure

Claim submission procedures are as follows:

  • The customer reimbursement amount should be entered in the “Sublet” field of the actual campaign claim.
  • All supporting documentation regarding the customer's invoice is still required as per the normal original process as stated on the Recall Campaign bulletin.
  • If the Owner is still in possession of the vehicle with an Open Recall Campaign the dealer must arrange to close the Recall Campaign in the usual manner (by performing the repair completely as stated in the Recall Campaign bulletin).
  • Whether or not the prior repair was performed at an independent repair facility or at a Mercedes-Benz Authorized Dealership, total reimbursement requested must be submitted as a “Sublet" on the actual campaign claim.

rh:doc.headline: CV 10.4 Recall and Service Campaign Review Prior to Delivery
rh:doc.parentIdentifier10: CV 10.4 Recall and Service Campaign Review Prior to Delivery

articles.content: Policy

MBUSA requires that all dealers maintain a policy in which all vehicles being serviced are routinely checked via NetStar for open recalls and service campaigns. If recall work is needed, the dealer shall advise the owner and complete the work as soon as possible. Compliance with these requirements is important for safety and satisfaction of our customers. An amendment to the National Traffic and Motor Vehicle Safety Act of 1966 addresses the dealer's responsibility in the retail/lease delivery of new vehicles.
Requirement

• Specifically, before a new vehicle may be delivered for sale or lease, the dealer is required by Federal Law to perform all Recall and Service Campaign work applicable to the subject vehicle, if not already performed.
  • The amendment states that dealers must assure that all new vehicles and any replacement items are free of safety defects and comply with all applicable Federal Motor Vehicle Safety Standards at the time of delivery to the consumer.
  • This amendment concurs with MBUSA’s existing New Vehicle Delivery Certification policy. The PDI checklist states that all new vehicles must be inspected for the need to perform any applicable Recall/Service Campaigns, and perform any work required as indicated by VMI.
  • As a result of this amendment, it is a violation of Federal Law to sell or lease a new vehicle without assuring that any or all applicable Recall and Service Campaigns have been performed.
  • Independent from the above-mentioned amendment to the Safety Act, a review of open Recall and Service Campaigns is also required before the sale or lease of a pre-owned vehicle.
  • In general, this applies to all (Recall, Service, safety-related and emissions-related) Campaigns.
Policy

After the dealership receives initial campaign parts stock, the dealership should check daily on how many vehicles are scheduled for the campaign and adjust or place subsequent parts orders with the dealer’s MBUSA Parts Distribution Center (PDC).

  • In some instances, parts are manufactured specifically for a Recall Campaign and cannot be used at a later time for replacement parts. Only the amount of parts required must be ordered by a dealer for a Recall Campaign to avoid overstocking and supply problems.

articles.attachmentTitle: Campaign Parts Ordered, Repair Completed on Later Date - NCU Feb 2020

articles.content: Policy

Upon completion of the necessary repairs for the Recall and/or Service Campaigns, the dealer is required to submit a campaign claim in a timely manner. (See Claim Submission policy section for further information).

If a claim is prematurely submitted, the vehicle campaign status may be incorrectly reported. An incorrect status would constitute a noncompliance with federal regulation § 573.15 “Public Availability of motor vehicle recall information” and subject both the dealership and MBUSA to monetary fines.
Requirement

For claim submission, the damage code(s) and labor operation number(s) are listed on the Work Instructions of the Recall or Service Campaign Bulletin.

If a recall claim is submitted prior to the recall completion, dealers will be permitted to claim the part only so that there is a record that it was replaced. The claim will need to be entered in full, with the labor and handling percentages adjusted to 0%. A OneTrac case under the EVA: Campaigns case type will need to be opened to allow the claim in.
Policy

Dealer must inform the customer of the open Recall or Service Campaign and perform it unless the customer declines and signs off on the RO that they have declined the work. The completion details of a Recall Campaign are closely tracked and monitored by the applicable governing agency (i.e. NHTSA, EPA, and CARB).
Guideline/Practical Example

Always review VMI before performing a Recall Campaign to verify that the Recall Campaign is required on the specific vehicle. If the Recall Campaign Bulletin does not agree with VMI, VMI overrides the Recall Campaign Bulletin for a vehicle’s inclusion. Recall Campaigns do not expire and may be performed on any vehicle flagged in VMI.
Policy

Recall and Service Campaigns section contains the policies and procedures that should be adhered to when administering and performing Recall and Service Campaigns on Mercedes-Benz vehicles. MBUSA requires that all dealers maintain a policy in which all vehicles being serviced are routinely checked via NetStar VMI for open recalls and service campaigns. If recall work is needed, the dealer shall advise the owner and complete the work as soon as possible.

Welcome to the Commercial Van Warranty Manual

The Commercial Van Warranty Manual is available on-line for your convenience. This manual is your reference guide to the current policies, procedures, requirements, and guidelines for administering warranty programs for Commerical Vehicles which are compulsory to everyone concerned.

Dealership personnel should be familiar with the content to ensure your dealership’s compliance to MBUSA warranty requirements. In doing so, this will assure correct processing of warranty claims and increased profitability of the dealership.

The information included in this Manual is of a confidential nature; it is not to be distributed and is intended for the exclusive use of your Commerical Van dealership personnel. The manual is considered a living document and as a best practice should be reviewed routinely in order to incorporate any necessary changes into your current processes.

Printed versions of this manual are considered obsolete at time of print.
